snippet: Last month’s devastating blast in West, Tex., did little to shake local skepticism of government regulations, and recent efforts to push for more oversight have faced strong resistance.
abstract: Devastating fertilizer plant blast in West, Tex, in April did little to shake local skepticism of government regulations, and recent efforts to push for more oversight have faced strong resistance; Texas has always prided itself on its free-market posture and its antipathy toward regulation, but it also had the nation's highest number of workplace fatalities for much of the past decade.

byline.original: By IAN URBINA, MANNY FERNANDEZ and JOHN SCHWARTZ
byline.contributor: Kitty Bennett contributed research from St. Petersburg, Fla., and Annie Lowrey contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Last month’s devastating blast in West, Tex., did little to shake local skepticism of government regulations, and recent efforts to push for more oversight have faced strong resistance.

headline.seo: After Explosion, Texas Remains Wary of Regulation
headline.main: After Plant Explosion, Texas Remains Wary of Regulation
headline.print_headline: After Plant Explosion, Texas Remains Wary of Regulation
